The story picks up directly after Gothic. The nameless hero (a running gag, as he‚Äôs always interrupted whenever he tries to introduce himself) has destroyed the barrier and freed the prisoners, but ended up trapped himself. His mentor, Xardas, rescues him in a weakened state after some time has passed, just as a new and greater threat emerges on the island of Khorinis. Meanwhile, on the mainland, the war against the orcs is going poorly, and the king has sent his paladins to secure as much magic ore as possible since magic weapons are humanity‚Äôs best chance. On Khorinis, the king‚Äôs increasing taxes have sparked uprisings among the people.

The game shines in its characters, humor, and world. The story is excellent, full of twists and surprises, and it‚Äôs especially rewarding for players of the first game you‚Äôll reunite with old friends and be hit with waves of nostalgia. Gothic II is a prime example of how to create memorable NPCs you genuinely care about. The lore and world building are expanded with more about the gods, faith, politics, and society. As before, you‚Äôll need to choose a faction, and there are rumors of a hidden thieves‚Äô guild not to mention a chance to revisit some familiar places. [b]Gothic 2[/b] starts right after the events of [b]Gothic 1[/b] and remains faithful to the original formula: a detailed, scenic world, open to satisfactory exploration as your skill and equipment allow; advancing ranks in morally ambiguous factions; skill acquisition through trainers; strict build focus (melee, ranged, or magic); restrictive armour-dependent survivability; early grind and late-game overpowerment; and, of course, the charming mandatory address: "Hey you!". Several key NPCs from the first game also play a prominent role in the second, and during the second chapter, you get to revisit the Valley of Mines, where the first game took place.

[b]Gothic 2[/b] stands out with detailed multi-stage investigation quests that take you to multiple beautiful locations across different biomes, featuring interesting characters with their own distinct personalities and daily routines. This all adds to the immersiveness that the game series is beloved for by its fans.

[b]Night of the Raven[/b] adds even more of that, effectively doubling the game's content. It also ramps up the difficulty quite a bit. Overcoming this requires a lot of grinding in the early game, which may feel overwhelming at times, as does the amount of extra information and quests thrown at you from the beginning. However, this is balanced by an additional game area with new biomes, three new factions, stronger weapons, and an intricate quest line that integrates nicely into the main game.

Aside from some poorly communicated hints in certain quests and the constant backtracking (which is less problematic once you get a hold of teleportation stones), there isn't really much to complain about. [b]Gothic 2[/b] is a solid genre classic that, above all, offers an immersive and exciting world that's fun to explore.

I greatly recommend it to all fans of dark fantasy and hope that, someday, it will receive a remake just like the first game did.

[b]My overall rating[/b]: [u]9/10[/u]
